script.speaker: David
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, I have to start with a mystery that's baffled people for generations. In Genesis 3, the Fall of Adam and Eve seems like pure tragedy—they're cast out of Eden into pain and death. But then in Moses 5:10-11, Adam says, 'This thing I know: I do not know save the Lord commanded me,' and suddenly they are glad. What flipped the script?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, that's the perfect hook to unlock the restored perspective on the Fall. The book of Moses reveals it's not a tragedy at all, but the essential step for growth in God's plan. To solve this, we need to dive into what the angel taught them in Moses 5:4-15.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Wait, glad after losing paradise? That's fascinating. Tell me more about this shift.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Notice this in Moses 5:9-12: Adam and Eve first wonder why they must offer sacrifices, but after the angel explains the plan of redemption, they exclaim, 'we know nothing about it save it were commanded of God. ... Adam fell that men might be; and men are, that they might have joy.' Their eyes open to the bigger picture.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's remarkable! So ancient Israel reading Genesis 3 might see only loss, but the restored view in Moses shows purpose.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. From ancient Israel's perspective, it's curse and expulsion in Genesis 3:16-19. Christ's view through Moses 4-5 frames it as necessary opposition for agency and progression. And modern Saints see it as the door to 'the joy of our redemption' in Moses 5:11.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I love that multi-perspective lens. How does this pattern of opposition play out across dispensations?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Here's where it gets powerful. Notice this pattern starting with Adam in Moses 4:1-4: Satan seeks to destroy agency, but Heavenly Father and Jesus protect our right to choose. Lehi echoes it in 2 Nephi 2:11-20, teaching 'opposition in all things' is essential for agency.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Hold that thought—Satan's role there is chilling. Keep going.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Lehi continues in 2 Nephi 2:25-30: 'Adam fell that men might be; and men are, that they might have joy.' Sound familiar? Then Alma 12:21-37 expands on how the Fall brings a state to try us, linking back to Moses. And Doctrine and Covenants 29:39-43 confirms the Fall was part of the plan.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I never saw that web so clearly across Adam, Lehi, Alma, and modern revelation. That's profound.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, trace it further: Elder Dale G. Renlund taught, 'Our Heavenly Father’s goal ... is to have His children choose to do what is right and ultimately become like Him.' This mirrors Moses 4:1-4 perfectly.

script.speaker: David
script.text: So opposition isn't just ancient—it's the thread through every dispensation. Now, let's deepen this with some cultural context from their story.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: What most people miss is the symbolism of nakedness and clothing in Moses 4:13-16, 27. After eating the fruit, Adam and Eve sew fig leaves to cover themselves, but the Lord God clothes them properly. This represents spiritual vulnerability and divine protection.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Fig leaves versus God's clothing? That's striking. How does that connect broader?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Notice these cross-references: Revelation 7:9, 13-15 describes the righteous in white robes; 2 Nephi 9:14 warns of standing naked before God without atonement; Doctrine and Covenants 109:22-26, 76 speaks of temple clothing. It's a pattern of covenant covering.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's remarkable! It makes the ancient event feel so immediate, like it's speaking to us in temples today.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. And there's a video in the Gospel Library called 'Sacred Temple Clothing' that ties right into this.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Now, circling back to our mystery—how does the angel resolve their confusion and make them glad?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: In Moses 5:4-15, after leaving Eden, Adam calls upon God in prayer, and an angel appears. The angel teaches the entire plan: sacrifices in similitude of the Son's atonement, redemption from the Fall. That's when they grasp it—opposition leads to joy through Christ.

script.speaker: David
script.text: So the Fall's 'tragedy' dissolves into hope. 'Because of Him'—like the video says.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes! Search Genesis 3:1-7 and Moses 4:22-31 for Fall effects, then Moses 5:4-15 for redemption. They were 'glad' because they saw Jesus Christ overcomes it all.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Powerful resolution. What other hidden connections pop out here?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Satan's tactics in Moses 4:4-12 and 5:13-33—he tempts to deceive and blind, just as with Eve and later Cain. But God counters with truth, like protecting agency.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Cain's story hits hard. Why accept Abel's sacrifice but not Cain's in Moses 5:16-26?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Notice the attitudes: Abel offers with a willing, obedient heart; Cain does not. God asks us to sacrifice with real intent today, shaping how we approach covenants.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's a surprise cross-reference most miss. And Genesis 3:16 or Moses 4:22 on Adam ruling over Eve?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Often misunderstood, but 'The Family: A Proclamation to the World' clarifies husbands and wives as equal partners. Elder Dale G. Renlund describes a righteous husband ministering, praising, respecting—like blessing the family.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I never connected that ancient phrase to modern prophetic counsel so directly.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Elder Ulisses Soares's video on 'Equal Partnership in Marriage' explains it perfectly.

script.speaker: David
script.text: How do these ancient patterns apply to our lives right now?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: In this fallen world, like Adam and Eve, we face opposition but can choose right with agency protected by God and Christ. For the Strength of Youth says 'Make inspired choices'—echoing Moses 4:1-4.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And opposition builds joy, per 2 Nephi 2:25 and Mosiah 3:19.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Precisely. The Fall links to the plan of salvation: facing opposition, repenting, trusting the Atonement for progression and becoming like Him.

script.speaker: David
script.text: It ties ancient Israel, Christ's teachings, and our dispensation together seamlessly.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Modern prophets mirror it, like Dallin H. Oaks on 'Opposition in All Things.' We see the same truths differently but unified.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, this conversation has transformed how I read Genesis 3-4 and Moses 4-5.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: As you study this week, list Fall effects and Christ's redemption, like in the lesson. Ponder agency in Moses 4:1-4 with 2 Nephi 2.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And teach your family why the Fall matters—using pictures from Old Testament Stories or completing 'Because of the Fall, I ... Because of Jesus Christ, I ...'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Pray like Adam in Moses 5:4, 8 to feel near Heavenly Father. Notice Satan's deceptions today from Moses 5:13-33 and resist.

script.speaker: David
script.text: What a journey from mystery to joy. Thanks, Sarah—listeners, dive into these scriptures and see the plan unfold.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It's all about choosing joy through opposition and Christ. Until next time!
